what the term implies um so first of all hello welcome to the stream um and second of all to answer your
question a service mesh um is what we call uh
a tool that you kind of use at a platform level so in a kubernetes cluster you usually
have a lot of services that are running there are usually microservices or distributed systems
this is not necessarily about that but a service mesh helps you achieve a couple of things at that platform
level so you can get security observability um and that kind of stuff at a platform level
rather than doing it at an application level um and the second part about your question with sidecars and
the way that services connect to each other and talk to each other that's kind of an implementation detail about service meshes because
with linker d1 for example it wasn't working with a sidecar pattern and by the way we're talking about
linker d2 today we also have a link rd1 version written on the jvm you know speaking about java developers
um but those sidecar patterns are a way to run your service mesh um
and why don't i just actually go to the docs so we're on the lingerie website now and i'm still going to answer your
question don't worry but i just want to go to to this reference page because we have an architecture diagram and i think
it's going to help exemplify everything a bit better so the way link rd works as a service
mesh is that it's split into two parts it has a control plane and a data pin and you can see this over
here the control plane are a set of components that we use to make some informed decisions for
example we have a destination service that we use to kind of resolve destination targets and don't
worry i'm going to get to that part in a second we have an identity component to manage certificates and stuff like that
um the real magic in a service mesh and certainly in in linkery's case
comes from the data plane so we have what's called a proxy that you can kind of inject next to your
container so in kubernetes a pod can have any number of containers
it's not restricted to just one container where your application runs so a side current pattern essentially
means we add another container with this proxient that will be responsible for handling
all of your network calls so if before your application would talk directly to a service
now the proxy will pick up that network communication and forward it on your behalf and this
allows us to do a bunch of stuff such as encrypting your calls because now your connection goes in the same
container while in the same pod it goes to a different container so it goes directly to linker d it's pretty secure and then from that
point on linkery encrypts it and forwards it encrypt it to the destination where it does the reverse it unencrypts
it and sends it to the application um it also allows you to pull metrics because now you can kind of have that
control over the networking calls and a bunch of stuff around it such as
load balancing and other nice things like that and for load balancing and all of the
added functionality we use the control plane like i said before so you know you want to talk to a service the proxy first looks at the
network request and it's like okay well where do we need to go we need to go to service b do we know anything about
service b's endpoints so it goes to the destination service fetches all of that data and
then makes an informed decision so uh yeah i don't know if it's uh if it's a complicated view on things
uh david let me know if i should simplify it a bit but in a nutshell that's kind of what it means we take
over your network connections we forward them for you and in the process we make everything better we
give you observability reliability and security i think that one liner is great there just

we actually don't have a lot of stuff in at the moment so what we're left with is a proxy injector
this is what we use to inject proxies uh as a sidecar into your application so
when you install linker d you install the control plane and everything is nice linkery can you know function properly
but when you want to add it to your application we need to inject the sidecar that's what we call
it um and you can do this on your own um but it's generally kind of uh kind of a lot of
yaml files to write and you know the less yaml we write i think the better we are off um
so we provide automatic injection you put an annotation on your kubernetes object and you say
okay i want this to be injected with the linkard data plane and the proxy injector will do that for you um and for those that are interested
under the hood it's a kubernetes mutating web hook um so it's
a web hook server and it ties in with the kubernetes web hooks system
then we have an identity component the identity component is used to
issue certificates to the proxies so the way we install inquiry usually is we have two certificates we have a root
trust certificate that should ideally you know not change very often and then we have an issuer certificate
that's used to sign other certificates and um you know the whole pki kind of aspect of it is a bit confusing
but what you need to know is that every proxy will get its own certificate every 24 hours and it will use the
certificate to encrypt your connections to have mtls um and the identity service
is responsible for scoping those certificates to be 24 hours and when they expire to reissue them
so yeah that's the second part and finally um probably the component
that i worked with most it's the destination service so you can actually see me i'm the last
one who committed code here um the destination service is how we kind of manage service discovery
in kubernetes so i previously said that you know we do some service discovery
up to a certain point so we can do a lot balancing and you know provide retries and timeouts and all of that stuff so
everything related to that is in this destination component and that's it
